None of that may trouble you or disturb your belief in your own righteousness. But if so, I can‚Äôt pretend I care much about your bad opinion of me. 11/11

Carl Henegan, professor of evidence-based medicine at Oxford University, has described the off-label use of puberty blockers on under-18s as an ‚Äòunregulated live experiment on children‚Äô. 
10/11

The long-term health risks of cross-sex hormones have been now been tracked over a lengthy period. These side-effects are often minimised or denied by trans activists.

9/11
Sophie is a trans woman and a true feminist ally. She was making the point that anti-depressants were over-prescribed to teenagers in the past, with serious consequences.  8/11

As I‚Äôve said many times, transition may be the answer for some. For others, it won‚Äôt ‚Äì witness the accounts of detransitioners.
‚ÄúThe system sees surgery as the easy fix to girls who do not conform.‚Äù
  7/11

These concerns were explored by the recent BBC documentary about the Tavistock Clinic. Whistleblowers were talking about transitions driven by homophobia. 
6/11

Many, myself included, believe we are watching a new kind of conversion therapy for young gay people, who are being set on a lifelong path of medicalisation that may result in the loss of their fertility and/or full sexual function. 5/11
Many health professionals are concerned that young people struggling with their mental health are being shunted towards hormones and surgery when this may not be in their best interests. 4/11

I‚Äôve written and spoken about my own mental health challenges, which include OCD, depression and anxiety. I did so recently in my essay ‚ÄòTERF Wars‚Äô. I‚Äôve taken anti-depressants in the past and they helped me. 3/11
When you lie about what I believe about mental health medication and when you misrepresent the views of a trans woman for whom I feel nothing but admiration and solidarity, you cross a line. 2/11
I've ignored fake tweets attributed to me and RTed widely. I've ignored porn tweeted at children on a thread about their art. I've ignored death and rape threats. I'm not going to ignore this. 1/11

I accept @lloyd_rm's apology in the hope that he‚Äôll dig a little deeper than hashtags and slogans. He might then understand why increasing numbers of people are deeply concerned about @UKLabour‚Äôs position on women‚Äôs rights. 9/9

Andrea Dworkin wrote: ‚ÄòMen often react to women‚Äôs words‚Äîspeaking and writing‚Äîas if they were acts of violence; sometimes men react to women‚Äôs words with violence.‚Äô It isn't hateful for women speak about their own experiences, nor do they deserve shaming for doing so. 8/9

When so-called leftists like @lloyd_rm demand that we give up our hard won sex-based rights, they align themselves squarely with men‚Äôs rights activists. To both groups, female trauma is white noise, an irrelevance, or else exaggerated or invented.  7/9

As I stated in my essay, my primary worry is the risks to vulnerable women. As everyone knows, I‚Äôm no longer reliant on communal facilities, nor am I likely to be imprisoned or need a women's refuge any time soon. I‚Äôm not arguing for the privileged, but the powerless. 6/9

Some emails came from professionals working in women‚Äôs refuges, the prison service, the social work system, the criminal justice system and the police. All expressed concerns about the aims and methods of current trans activism. 5/9

Since writing my essay, I‚Äôve received over 3000 emails thanking me for speaking up. I‚Äôve been brought to tears many times while reading, sometimes out of gratitude for their kindness, but also because many women have shared their own experiences of violence & sexual assault. 4/9

For those who‚Äôd like to know what triggered the shadow minister‚Äôs original accusation, these are the relevant paragraphs of the essay I wrote a couple of weeks ago. The full piece can be read here

This morning, Mr Russell-Moyle issued an apology on Twitter, although he didn‚Äôt trouble to tag me in. Coincidentally, his change of heart occurred after his remarks were repeated in national newspapers with higher circulations than @tribunemagazine. 2/9

Today I discovered that I was accused of hate by shadow environment minister Lloyd Russell-Moyle in the pages of @tribunemagazine. He claimed I was ‚Äòusing‚Äô my experiences of sexual assault and domestic violence to ‚Äòdiscriminate‚Äô against trans people. 1/9

"I've never felt as shouted down, ignored, and targeted as a lesbian *within* our supposed GLBT community as I have over the past couple of years."
RT @TwisterFilm: @jk_rowling has pinpointed why so many gay peeps are concerned about the new version of trans activism. We used to be comr‚Ä¶

I respect every trans person‚Äôs right to live any way that feels authentic and comfortable to them. I‚Äôd march with you if you were discriminated against on the basis of being trans. At the same time, my life has been shaped by being female. I do not believe it‚Äôs hateful to say so.

The idea that women like me, who‚Äôve been empathetic to trans people for decades, feeling kinship because they‚Äôre vulnerable in the same way as women - ie, to male violence - ‚Äòhate‚Äô trans people because they think sex is real and has lived consequences - is a nonsense.

‚ÄòFeminazi‚Äô, ‚ÄòTERF‚Äô, ‚Äòbitch‚Äô, ‚Äòwitch‚Äô. 
Times change. Woman-hate is eternal.

One of my best mates just called me. Self-described butch lesbian. It was hard to tell, because she was shouting quite loudly, but I could just make out ‚ÄòFUCKING YES!‚Äô

I‚Äôve spent much of the last three years reading books, blogs and scientific papers by trans people, medics and gender specialists. I know exactly what the distinction is. Never assume that because someone thinks differently, they have no knowledge.

If sex isn‚Äôt real, there‚Äôs no same-sex attraction. If sex isn‚Äôt real, the lived reality of women globally is erased. I know and love trans people, but erasing the concept of sex removes the ability of many to meaningfully discuss their lives. It isn‚Äôt hate to speak the truth.

8/13

Anyway, over the last few weeks I‚Äôve done a bit of rewriting 
and I‚Äôve decided to publish the Ickabog for free online, 
so children on lockdown, or even those back at school during these strange, unsettling times, can read it or have it read to them.

7/13

Absolutely no idea what inspired this doodle.

6/13

Opening the box was like opening a time capsule. Most of the story was handwritten, but bits had been typed up. When I put it into some kind of order (I'm not renowned for my filing skills) I had a patchwork first draft.

5/13

Over time I came to think of The Ickabog as just for my family. The manuscript went up into the attic, where it remained until a few weeks ago. 

This is the very dusty box I got down from the attic. 
(It's a Net-A-Porter box and might well have held a premiere dress.)

4/13

I always meant to publish it, but after the last Potter 
was released I wrote two novels for adults and, after some dithering, decided to put those out next.

Until very recently, the only people who‚Äôd heard the story of 
The Ickabog were my two younger children.

3/13

Over 10 years ago, I wrote a stand-alone fairy tale called 
The Ickabog. You can read more about how, why and 
when The Ickabog was written at 

2/13

I have a small announcement, but before I get started, I
want to head off one possible source of confusion.

* If you define the birthplace of Harry Potter as the moment when I had the initial idea, then it was a Manchester-London train. But I'm perennially amused by the idea that Hogwarts was directly inspired by beautiful places I saw or visited, because it's so far from the truth.

This is the true birthplace of Harry Potter, if you define 'birthplace' as the spot where I put pen to paper for the first time.* I was renting a room in a flat over what was then a sports shop. The first bricks of Hogwarts were laid in a flat in Clapham Junction.
I saw that sign when I was in there a couple of years ago and it made me laugh. I‚Äôm thinking of going and writing in there one day so they have to correct it: ‚Äò.... except that one time.‚Äô
For instance, I never visited this bookshop in Oporto. Never even knew of its existence! It‚Äôs beautiful and I wish I *had* visited it, but it has nothing to do with Hogwarts!

I was thinking of putting a section on my website about all the alleged inspirations and birthplaces of Potter. I‚Äôd been writing Potter for several years before I ever set foot in this cafe, so it‚Äôs not the birthplace, but I *did* write in there so we‚Äôll let them off!
